title: 111_hr768
content: The "Commission on Financial Crisis Accountability Act of 2009" establishes a commission known as the "Commission on Financial Crisis Accountability" with specific duties. The Commission on Financial Crisis Accountability Act of 2009 establishes a commission to study the financial system in the United States, focusing on the causes and impact of the current financial crisis, regulation, transparency, fraud, tax treatments, and the role of various participants in the financial services industry. The Commission on Financial Crisis Accountability Act of 2009 establishes a commission to study the financial system in the United States, focusing on the causes and impact of the current financial crisis, regulation, transparency, fraud, tax treatments, and the role of various participants in the financial services industry. The Commission will report its findings to Congress, including details on the causes of the crisis and recommendations for addressing them. The Commission on Financial Crisis Accountability Act of 2009 establishes a commission to study the causes and impact of the current financial crisis, including recommendations for avoiding future crises, the current stage of the crisis, its impact on Federal revenues, restructuring the financial regulatory structure, and making tax treatment of financial products more fair. Additionally, the Commission will make recommendations for a Shareholder Bill of Rights to protect investors' rights and savings. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with qualifications in relevant matters and no conflicts of interest. Members serve for the duration of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chair of the Commission is designated by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, with appointments to be made within 30 days of enactment. Members are paid based on the Executive Schedule level IV rate for their duties, with a prohibition on compensation for federal employees. Members of the Commission who are full-time officers or employees of the United States may not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits. Each member shall receive travel expenses and per diem. Retired annuitants on the Commission are exempt from certain provisions. A majority of members constitute a quorum for meetings. The Commission's meetings are scheduled by the Speaker of the House within 30 days of all members being appointed. Subsequent meetings are called by the Chair as needed. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chair, paid at a rate not exceeding GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Chair may appoint up to 3 staff members with pay not exceeding GS-15. The Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Chair of the Commission can request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist in carrying out duties under this Act. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain information from US agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and use the US mails. Administrative support services can be requested as needed. The Commission has the authority to request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 90 days of its appointment, and it will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report. Appropriations are authorized as needed for the Act.
